conclusion: To determine the amount of charge passing through R1 after the switch S is opened, we need to follow these steps:
When the switch S is closed, the circuit is in a steady state. The capacitors C1 and C2 are in parallel with the resistors R1 and R2.

premise: The total resistance R_total = R1 + R2 = 4.0Ω + 6.0Ω = 10.0Ω.
conclusion: The voltage across the resistors (and thus the capacitors) is V = E/R_total × R2 = 10V/10Ω × 6Ω = 6V.
The charge on each capacitor when the switch is closed is Q1 = C1 × V = 30μF × 6V = 180μC and Q2 = C2 × V = 30μF × 6V = 180μC.
When the switch S is opened, the capacitors are in series.
The total capacitance C_total in series is 1/C_total = 1/C1 + 1/C2 = 1/30μF + 1/30μF = 2/30μF, so C_total = 30μF/2 = 15μF.
The voltage across the series combination is V_total = Q_total/C_total = 360μC/15μF = 24V.
The voltage across C1 after the switch is opened is V1 = R1/(R1 + R2) × V_total = 4.0Ω/10.0Ω × 24V = 9.6V.
The new charge on C1 is Q1' = C1 × V1 = 30μF × 9.6V = 288μC.
The charge passing through R1 is the difference in charge on C1: ΔQ = Q1' - Q1 = 288μC - 180μC = 108μC.
